oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Case report: An Investigation of Dairy Cow Teat Lesions and Clinical Mastitis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kirk, John H.
Sischo, William M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: bovine mastitis
case reports
clinical aspects
cows
dairy cows
hyperkeratosis
lesions
mammary gland diseases
mastitis
reviews
teats
warts
cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A California dairyman milking 1,969 cows reported excessive cases of clinical mastitis, and questioned whether teat-end lesions were associated with the problem. Using a system of teat-end lesion classification, the entire milking herd was observed for lesions during January 2002. Overall, 9.9% of the herd had some type of lesion, including warts and severe hyperkeratosis; 67% of lesions were severe teat-end hyperkeratosis. Cows with teat lesions were three times more at risk of clinical mastitis compared to cows without teat lesions. Because of physical limitations of the milking equipment and the ownerâ€™s reluctance to modify the milking routine, no management changes were made.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Bovine Practitioner; Vol. 37, No. 1 (2003 February); 30-34
